title: Inspector general, police monitor agree to separate offices
text:
NEW ORLEANS (AP) - A feud between New Orleans' inspector general and the city's independent police monitor has apparently ended with an agreement that their respective offices will be run separately.
Inspector General Ed Quatrevaux said in a Wednesday news release that he and police monitor Susan Hutson agreed to seek a city charter change to separate their offices. The police monitor currently is part of the inspector general's office.
Quatrevaux said an agreement signed in the office of City Council member Jared Brossett calls for separation of the agencies and dedicated funding from the city's general fund to the police monitor.
Hutson and Quatrevaux have been in disputes over funding. Quatrevaux last month called for the local Ethics Review Board to fire Hutson. He said she overstepped her authority, an accusation she denied.
